subcourses.label: AWS
subcourses.heading: Amazon Web Services (AWS) - Cloud Computing Services
subcourses.content: Amazon Web Services is a subsidiary of Amazon.com that provides on-demand cloud computing platforms to individuals, companies and governments, on a paid subscription basis

subcourses.label: Azure
subcourses.heading: Microsoft Azure is a cloud computing service
subcourses.content: Microsoft Azure is a cloud computing service created by Microsoft for building, testing, deploying, and managing applications and services through a global network of Microsoft-managed data centers

subcourses.label: Google Engine
subcourses.heading: Google App Engine is a web framework and cloud computing
subcourses.content: Google App Engine is a web framework and cloud computing platform for developing and hosting web applications in Google-managed data centers. Applications are sandboxed and run across multiple servers.

subcourses.label: IBM BlueMix
subcourses.heading: IBM Bluemix is a cloud platform as a service developed by IBM
subcourses.content: IBM Bluemix is a cloud platform as a service developed by IBM. It supports several programming languages and services as well as integrated DevOps to build, run, deploy and manage applications on the cloud.

subcourses.label: MVC
subcourses.heading: Model–view–controller is an architectural pattern
subcourses.content: Model–view–controller is an architectural pattern commonly used for developing user interfaces that divides an application into three interconnected parts.

subcourses.label: ASP .NET
subcourses.heading: ASP.NET is an open-source server-side web application framework
subcourses.content: ASP.NET is an open-source server-side web application framework designed for web development to produce dynamic web pages. It was developed by Microsoft to allow programmers to build dynamic web sites, web applications and web services.

subcourses.label: C#
subcourses.heading: C# is a multi-paradigm programming language
subcourses.content: C# is a multi-paradigm programming language encompassing strong typing, imperative, declarative, functional, generic, object-oriented, and component-oriented programming disciplines.
